TORONTO, CANADA / ACCESSWIRE / August 28, 2019 / As fires rage in the largest Rainforest in the world, global concern is mounting over the lack of preventative measures that could have been taken to avoid large-scale fires in the world's most vital carbon store. The Amazonian Rainforest produces 20% of the world's oxygen and is also home to approximately three million species of plants and animals and one million indigenous people.

EcoForests CEO Michael Ackerman has called on government officials to "learn from privately owned plantations where risk levels for fires are minimal." With consistent pruning, cleaning, and organic fertilization to eliminate weeds that typically start forest fires, the risk is substantially lowered for fires to start and spread on a widespread basis.

Applying Lessons from the Private Sector to National Forests

A Hancock Timber Resource group study found that with $300 Billion invested in managed forests across the globe, less than .05% is affected by forest fire or flood. According to Ackerman, "Forestry investment plantations receive considerable checks-and-balances that care-taking and management of plantations is optimal. There is a need for additional resources and political willingness to improve the management of state-owned forestlands. With the technology and safety measures available today, the Amazon forest crisis should not be happening."

An example of positive resource allocation and political willingness to protect its forestland is Honduras, which has recently made great strides to protect federal plantations. In 2013, Honduras became the first country in Latin America to initiate negotiations for a Voluntary Partnership Agreement (VPA) under the European Union's Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade (FLEGT) Action Plan to create systems that improve forest management and incentivize responsible operations. Similarly, Costa Rica, which lost about two-thirds of its Rainforest from 1950-1987 due to deforestation and government inaction, has doubled its forest cover in the last 30 years, after introducing stricter federal management policies.

Upcoming EcoForests Projects

As part of its Impact Investing mandate and commitment to sustainable forestry practices, EcoForests is excited to introduce several upcoming agricultural-forestry ("agroforestry") projects in South America, with a focus on Ecuador and Colombia, two nations with strong forestry protection laws. These projects will each centre around the harvesting of cacao beans and continue EcoForests' sustainable operating principles into the agroforestry sector.

About EcoForests

EcoForests is a boutique forestry investment management company that manages high-end tropical timber species on behalf of their global private and institutional investors, maximizing returns through a commitment to quality, technique, sustainability and security. Headquartered in Toronto, EcoForests has forestry operations in Central and South America with regional offices in Hong Kong, USA, Israel and UK.

James Johnston of the Lethbridge detatchment.</p><p>Samantha Grant, a spokeswoman for STARS air ambulance, said an 80-year-old woman was flown from the Fort Macleod hospital to Calgary with second-and-third-degree burns.</p><p>All 350 residents of Granum and another 250 people from the surrounding area were sent to neighboring Claresholm as a grass fire burned close to the town, about 130 kilometres south of Calgary.</p><p>However, most were allowed to return home later in the evening after the danger had passed.</p><p>Claresholm Mayor Ernie Patterson said not all residents of the region were as lucky: "There are some families who have lost their homes. It's just been a calamity.''</p><p>Stan Byers and his wife Clara saw their place outside the village burn to the ground.</p><p>"I just don't know what we are going to do. Other people get to go home now, but where do we go? Nowhere,'' said a shocked Stan Byers. "I just stood there looking for that ray of hope the fire would pass by the house.''</p><p>Patterson said firefighting efforts and a lucky shift in the wind stopped the blaze right on the edge of Granum.</p><p>"We've had no snow,'' Patterson said of local conditions. "The forest fire hazard is extremely high.''</p><p>The blaze, which fire officials said had burned 100 square kilometres of land, also forced the closure of Highway 2 and prompted women and children to flee the Keho Hutterite colony.</p><p>It was a sad scene at the Claresholm high school, where about 60 evacuees awaited the chance to return to Granum. Many hugged and cried as they consoled each other.</p><p>"I'm holding out hope, that's all I can do,'' said long-time Granum resident Ray Raine, who took his dog Bernie with him as he fled his home.</p><p>Eileen Cooper of Barons, a town just east of Granum, said the fire was an eerie sight.</p><p>"While the sun was out we could see what seemed like a mixture of billowing sand and smoke. At one time the sun was rust-red,'' she said.</p><p>One of the fires at Hinton, 300 kilometres west of Edmonton, was believed to have started Saturday night when an electrical pole toppled over and was fuelled by winds of up to 80 kilometres an hour.</p><p>Rocky Notnes saw his two-storey log home burn to the ground, along with a garage and several cars.</p><p>"We just woke up because the house was filling with smoke,'' he said. "We went outside and saw the fire. The wind was so strong we knew it could come this way, and then as we were speaking, there was just fire literally dropping from the sky.</p><p>"We headed straight down to the river in the moonlight. It's a miracle that no one was killed.'' Firefighter Perry Hayward said the winds were unbelievably strong.</p><p>"It was really jumping all over the place. It was bad enough that some residents of Hinton were told to be ready to evacuate at any time if the wind shifted.''</p><p>Most veteran firefighters said they had never worked on a forest fire this late in the year.</p><p>"I was supposed to be decorating the Christmas tree and then going ice-fishing,'' said Dave Lind of Lac La Biche. "But it looks like I won't be back for maybe a week or so. We need the winds to calm down before we get this one under control.''</p><p>Evert Smith of Alberta's Land and Forest Service said one of the two fires covered 500 hectares north of the community. The second blaze, about 1,500 hectares in size, blazed about 30 kilometres south of the town.</p><p>Six water tankers, four helicopters and eight ground crews were fighting the fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5WKW-XY71-F103-33XY-00000-00Teen campers raise fire concerns near Murrayville2019-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:06:50ZLexisNexisNEWSTeen campers raise fire concerns near Murrayville

A Langley couple are worried that teens camping and starting fires in a ravine near their Murrayville home could spark a forest fire.

Jill and Patrick Spavor live near 224th Street on the edge between the suburban homes of Murrayville near Langley Memorial Hospital, and the Agricultural Land Reserve.

Jill recently noticed something was amiss during one of her walks down a trail that marks the right of way for the Township's water pipe to Aldergrove.

"It was the smell of smoke," she said.

The gravel path leads through a forested area covered with cottonwoods and cedar trees.

Near a bridge over a ravine, local dog walkers, hikers, and kids on bicycles have created paths that lead down into the ravine and wind through what is private, but undeveloped, forest property.

Two weeks ago, the smell of wood smoke led Jill to a camp set up by the stream bed by a group of teenagers.

They were camped there for several days, she said, and were burning wood most of the time.

"There was quite a fire pit there," she said.

The Spavors, worried about a spark in the woods after the long and dry spring, called the Township Fire Department.

Patrick led some firefighters to the site, and both Spavors spoke with the teens a couple of times over the course of a few days.

The teens told Patrick it was a grad camp out, he said.

Jill warned them about the possibility of fire travelling underground and getting away from them.

"They were very polite, but not keen on leaving," she said of the group.

The group eventually left the campsite, leaving behind a fire pit of blackened wood, a tent, and a considerable amount of food packaging and empty bottles, the Spavors said. They cleaned up most of the site and packed out the garbage.

The couple are worried about the possibility of other fires being set in the area by campers and getting out of control. On the east side of 224th Street there is dense bush, but the west side is single-family homes and it is just a few blocks to Langley Memorial Hospital.

Reports of incidents near the pipeline right of way have been handed over to the RCMP and Township bylaw officials, said deputy Township fire chief Russ Jenkins.

There have been reports of campfires in the area, and firefighters have gone out to check on the site, Jenkins said.

Speaking generally, Jenkins noted that even after recent rains, there are still sheltered areas and dry brush that could catch fire.

"There's a reason we have a burning ban," he noted.

Outside of defined periods in the spring and autumn, outdoor burning is completely banned in the Township, as in the rest of Metro Vancouver.

This year, the Township has already seen several mulch fires and small brush fires, including at the Langley Events Centre grounds and near McLeod Athletic Park.

Fires have been sparked by discarded cigarettes or homeless camps.

urn:contentItem:5SBJ-W0G1-F105-63WD-00000-00Muskoka fire rating listed as high, May 14; no daytime burning2018-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:06:50ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYPg. 1Muskoka fire rating listed as high, May 14; no daytime burning

MUSKOKA - Daytime burning is currently banned in the District of Muskoka.

Area municipalities have listed the fire danger rating as high as of Monday, May 14. The Muskoka fire season runs from April 1 to October 31 each year. The rating is verified daily and updated whenever the rating changes.

The Muskoka Fire Danger Rating is determined using the Fire Weather Index (FWI), an internationally used method for determining the risk of fires in open air. It uses factors such as the relative humidity, temperature, previous 24-hour rain amount, wind directions and wind speed in combination with the forest fuel type and loads to determine the risk of the forest to certain fire types. From this calculation the forest fire danger rating is made in consultation with the fire chiefs of the six area municipalities and the ministry of natural resources. What do the ratings mean?

Low Low danger of fire. You may conduct any municipally permitted fire activities. No daytime burning. Campfires for cooking and warmth only.

Moderate Moderate danger of fire. Carry out permitted fire activities with caution. No daytime burning. Campfire for cooking and warmth only. Carry out any burning with caution.

High High danger of fire. Only absolutely necessary municipally permitted activities should be carried out. However, it is recommended that no burning should occur. No daytime burning. Avoid campfires, even for cooking and warmth if possible. Fire danger is serious - use extreme caution.

Extreme Extremely high fire danger. Total fire ban. No burning allowed at any time of the day. No fires, including charcoal barbecues.

Fire Ban In some cases, should the fire danger rating be at high or extreme, the municipality should choose to issue a fire ban. When the fire ban is in place, no burning of any kind is permitted. Fireworks are not permitted. Fire ban in effect.

For daily updates and a verbal explanation of the current rating, please call the pre-recorded information line at: 1-877-847-1577.

THE</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">An evacuation alert was issued yesterday for 15,000 residents of the B.C. Interior by officials worried that gusty winds forecast for today could push a nearby forest fire into this lakeside city.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In a radio bulletin, Mayor Colin Mayes warned that residents should be ready to leave on 10 minutes notice today, taking only irreplaceable valuables and essentials such as clothing and medications.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Authorities planned a door-to-door canvass to explain the alert in detail and issue maps showing evacuation routes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">There was no immediate threat yesterday from the fire, which now covers more than 4,900 hectares south and west of town.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>CRISIS</p><p>The crisis, if it comes, will be this morning, when weather forecasters predict winds gusting up to 80 kilometres an hour could whip the fire into an inferno.</p><p>"In the meantime, residents should be prepared to leave," said Mayes.</p><p>"We're doing this as a preventive matter," added Bob Truly, an emergency organization director. "At this time, we don't want to create a panic or alarm situation."</p><p>Salmon Arm, in the Shuswap region of southern British Columbia, nestles between the fire-ravaged mountains and Shuswap Lake. The main route out of the city is the Trans-Canada Highway.</p><p>Mayes said reception centres would be set up in nearby communities where any Salmon Arm evacuees could seek emergency shelter.</p><p>If the alert is followed by an evacuation order for the city, the exodus would be unprecedented in local memory, said Mayes.</p><p>Four hundred to 600 people in the fire's path were forced to flee last Wednesday when 90 km/hr winds whipped up the flames and sent them toward the city.</p><p>The blaze raced across one valley in minutes, with a heat so intense that mature trees turned to blackened matchsticks in seconds. Some 40 buildings, including 16 homes in outlying areas, were destroyed.</p><p>But Mayes tried to quell any alarm.</p><p>"The fire's not going to be on us with like just minutes; we're going to have time," he said.</p><p>"We're forecasting these winds. We know when they're going to pick up. If the order comes in, we'll simply start on the areas closest to the fire, then we'll move out from there."</p><p>The local hospital was evacuated last week when the fire first threatened the city. Yesterday, squads of volunteers were making arrangements for residents of senior citizens' lodges and anyone else who might have difficulty making their way to safety on their own.</p><p>"One of the key things is how long will these gusts last," said Anne Ferdinands, an information officer with the B.C. Forest Service.</p><p>The blaze is capricious, said fire boss Roy Benson, describing the situation as "the most extreme fire behaviour that any of us have ever seen."</p><p>A force of more than 300 firefighters, with more than a dozen helicopters and two giant Martin Mars water bombers attacking the fire from above, worked feverishly yesterday to extend fire guards around the perimeter of the blaze.</p><p>'FRESH LEGS'</p><p>They will be joined today by 100 soldiers from the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry Regiment, who underwent a day of training yesterday before heading to the fire line.</p><p>"We're here as fresh legs," said Maj. Dave Anderson. "The forest service has been at it for seven to 10 days now. The crews are getting tired and we're here to assist them."</p><p>The soldiers will be mainly assigned to mop up and contain the fire within its perimeter, said Anderson.</p><p>"It's unlikely that we'll be used after one day's training at the frontal end of the fire. We'll be used at the flanks to stop it from spreading."</p><p>The blaze now covers an area equal to almost 5,000 football fields. Every morning, Salmon Arm is covered in a pall of smoke that extends west toward Kamloops. The haze usually lifts by early afternoon, allowing helicopters and water bombers to see their targets.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Photo: Dave Olecko - The Calgary Herald; A helicopter takes off from Shuswap Lake after it picked up a load of water to attack the approaching fires in the hills around Salmon Arm, B.C. urn:contentItem:5T49-TVX1-F105-600X-00000-00Rainfall isn't enough to stop Mt. Hicks fire2018-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:06:50ZLexisNexisNEWSRainfall isn't enough to stop Mt. Hicks fire

Saturday's rainy, wet conditions in the Fraser Valley will do little to stop the raging Mt. Hicks wildfire as it continues to grow.

The latest update from the District of Kent says the fire – now a whopping 410 hectares in size and 45 per cent contained – has continued growing to the north and remains a threat to properties on Kamp Road.

PUBLIC NOTICEMt. Hicks Fire UpdateAugust 24, 2018Agassiz, British Columbia - The Seabird Island Band along with the District of Kent working with the BC Wildfire Service (BCWS) to combat the Mt. Hicks... https://t.co/gWRcJbpCUQ— Seabird Island Band (@SeabirdIsland) August 24, 2018

While cooler temperatures may discourage 'aggressive fire behaviour,' the anticipated rainfall is simply not enough to make any noticeable headway on the blaze, burning approximately 10 kilometres north of Agassiz.

The majority of the fire has been burning north towards Sasquatch Provincial Park and west towards Kamp Road, where properties remain on evacuation alert and will be notified in person if an evacuation order is made.

The deciding factor is the sprinkler containment line on the west flank – if the fire breaches the line, residents will be ordered to leave.

As of Saturday, the fire hasn't crossed the perimeter, and the southern flank of the fire, burning towards Seabird Island, has slowed and is burning a rank 1 – smoldering fire burning on the forest fire.

Seabird Island warns that airborne ash could land in surrounding communities and homeowners should eliminate combustible fire hazards.
